question.title: Problem 08.002 - Step function approximation

internal_category.title: Chapter: 08 System Analysis in the Time Domain
Topic: System Analysis in the Time Domain
ABET Outcomes: 1. an ability to identify, formulate, and solve complex engineering problems by applying principles of engineering, science, and mathematics

property.name: customType
property.value: Multiple Choice

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: A step function is a good representation of this input. Yes.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How long does it take for the speed in the model to reach a constant value?

worksheet.stem:
A rocket sled has the following idealized equation of motion: %media:formula55.mml%. Suppose the rocket motor actually takes 0.04 s to reach a constant thrust of 2700 N. Is a step function a good representation of this input? Support your answer with a calculation.

 

A step function is a good representation of this input.__ans__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
%media:formula462.mml%

 

τ = 0.25 sec

 

v(t) reaches steady state at t = 4τ.

 

Thus, the speed takes approximately 4(0.25) = 1 sec to reach constant speed. Because 0.04 sec is small compared to 1 sec, the answer is yes.

question.title: Problem 08.026.b - Stability of a second-order system

internal_category.title: Chapter: 08 System Analysis in the Time Domain
Topic: System Analysis in the Time Domain
ABET Outcomes: 1. an ability to identify, formulate, and solve complex engineering problems by applying principles of engineering, science, and mathematics

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
The roots are

 

%media:1formula447.mml%

 

There will be imaginary parts if f(b) = 9b2 − 5b + 10 < 0. Solving df/db = 0 gives b = 5/18. At b = 5/18, df2/db2 = 18 > 0, and thus, f(b) has a minimum value of f(5/18) = 9.305. Therefore, there is no real value of b for which 9b2 − 5b + 10 < 0, and thus, no decaying oscillations.

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: Therefore there is no real value of b for which 9b2 − 5b + 10 < 0, and thus no decaying oscillations.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What are the roots for the given equation?

multipleChoice.stem: Is there a value of b for which the free response will consist of decaying oscillations?
multipleChoice.commonFeedback:
The roots are

 

%media:1formula447.mml%

 

There will be imaginary parts if f(b) = 9b2 − 5b + 10 < 0. Solving df/db = 0 gives b = 5/18. At b = 5/18, df2/db2 = 18 > 0, and thus, f(b) has a minimum value of f(5/18) = 9.305. Therefore, there is no real value of b for which 9b2 − 5b + 10 < 0, and thus, no decaying oscillations.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: What is the formula to determine maximum overshoot?

worksheet.stem:
Compute the maximum percent overshoot, the maximum overshoot, the peak time, the 100% rise time, the delay time, and the 2% settling time for the following model. The initial conditions are zero. Time is measured in seconds.

 

%media:formula448.mml%

 

The maximum overshoot is __ans1__, the 100% rise time is __ans2__ s, the peak time is __ans3__ s, the delay time is __ans4__ s, and the 2% settling time is __ans5__.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
%media:formula455.mml%, which implies from Figure.a that the maximum percent overshoot is ≈ {{[A(4)]:#.###}}. Because xss = 2/8 = 0.25, the overshoot is {{[A(4)]:#.###}}(0.25) ≈ {{[A(5)]:#.###}}.

 

For ζ = {{[A(3)]:#.###}}, Figure.c shows that ωntr ≈ {{[A(6)]:#.###}}. Because ωn = √8/1 = 2√2, tr = {{[A(6)]:#.###}}/2√2 = {{[A(7)]:#.###}} s.

 

For ζ = {{[A(3)]:#.###}}, Figure.b shows that ωntp ≈ {{[A(8)]:#.###}}. Because ωn = 2√2, tp = {{[A(8)]:#.###}}/2√2 = {{[A(9)]:#.###}} s.

 

For ζ = {{[A(3)]:#.###}} and ωn = 2√2, Table.a gives td = {{[A(10)]:#.###}} s.

 

The roots are {{[A(13)]:#.###}} ± {{[A(14)]:#.###}}j, so the time constant is τ = {{[A(11)]:#.###}}. The 2% settling time is 4τ = {{[A(12)]:#.###}}.

Suppose that the resistance in the circuit given is {{[a]:0.##}}×106 Ω . A voltage is applied to the circuit and then is suddenly removed at time t = 0. The measured voltage across the capacitor is given in the following table. Use the data to estimate the value of the capacitance C.

6 9.8
8 9.2
10 8.6
12 8.0
14 7.5
16 7.0
18 6.6
20 6.2

 

The value of the capacitance C is __A__× 10–5 F.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The free response of the circuit is

 

%media:formula4.mml%

 

where τ = RC = 3 × 106C.

 

A plot of ln vC(t) versus t gives a straight line whose slope −1/τ is computed from

 

%media:formula5.mml%

 

Thus, τ = 1/0.033 = 30.286.

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value: When μ = 30, the root separation factor is 30/3 = 10. When μ = 6, the root separation factor is 6/3 = 2. When μ = 3, the root separation factor is 1. The above calculations are based on the dominant root approximation, which is less accurate when the root separation factor is small. Thus, the calculations for μ = 30 have the most accuracy, and those for μ = 3 have the least accuracy.

property.name: problemSolution
property.value: The case when μ = 3 exhibits least accuracy.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: Consider the effect of roots for higher order polynomial.

multipleChoice.stem: Which of following case give the least accuracy for the above?
multipleChoice.commonFeedback: When μ = 30, the root separation factor is 30/3 = 10. When μ = 6, the root separation factor is 6/3 = 2. When μ = 3, the root separation factor is 1. The above calculations are based on the dominant root approximation, which is less accurate when the root separation factor is small. Thus, the calculations for μ = 30 have the most accuracy, and those for μ = 3 have the least accuracy.

choice.distractor: All of them, have the same accuracy, provided μ > 3.

property.name: commonFeedback
property.value:
The transfer function is

 

%media:formula179.mml%

 

The MATLAB file can be written as follows:

den = [1,24,225,900,2500];

numa = [0.2,1];

sysa = tf(numa,den);

numb = [1,1];

sysb = tf(numb,den);

numc = [10,1];

sysc = tf(numc,den);

 

Type step(sysa) at the prompt to see the response for the case where a = 0.2. Then, right-click on the plot and select “Characteristics” to determine the overshoot, etc. Follow the same steps for the other two cases.

hint.name: hint #1
hint.value: How to find the dominant pair in a set of given roots?

worksheet.stem:
The characteristic roots are s = −3 ± 6j and −10 ± 2j. Find the dominant root pair.

 

The dominant root pair is __A__± __B__ j.
worksheet.commonFeedback:
The Matlab session to obtain the roots of the given polynomial is

 

roots([1,26,269,1524,4680])

 

ans =
-10.0000 + 2.0000i
-10.0000 - 2.0000i
-3.0000 + 6.0000i
-3.0000 - 6.0000i

 

So the dominant root pair is s = −3 ± 6j, which keeps the system response parameters more stable.
